frontmatter.title: Reducing the uncertainty about the uncertainties, part 1: Linear and nonlinear

children.value: In these posts I will review some general aspects of optimization-based state estimation methods, and how to input and output consistent quantities and uncertainties, i.e, covariance matrices, from them. We will take a (hopefully) comprehensive tour that will cover
why we do the things the way we do

things about working with covariances. We will see how most of the explanations naturally arise by making explicit the definitions and conventions that sometimes we implicitly assume when using these tools.
They summarize and extend some of the interesting discussions we had in the
group. We hope that such space will continue to bring to the table relevant questions shared by all of us.
A simple example: a pose graph

children.label: A simple example: a pose graph

children.value: As a motivation, we will use a similar pose graph to those used in other GTSAM examples:

We consider a robot moving on the 2D plane (top), which has an odometer that provides relative measurements of the robot's displacement. The graph at the bottom represent the factor graph model. Modeling the odometry factor in a consistent way is the main topic we will cover in these posts.
To start, we will consider that the variables in the graph

children.html: xi\mathbf{x}_ixi​
xi=(x,y)∈R2{\mathbf{x}_{i}} = (x,y) \in \mathbb{R}^2xi​=(x,y)∈R2

children.value: . The variables are related by a linear model given by a transition matrix

children.html: Ai\mathbf{A}_{i}Ai​
bi=(bx,by)\mathbf{b}_{i} = (b_x, b_y)bi​=(bx​,by​)

children.value: , which can be obtained from some sensor such as a wheel odometer. We can then establish the following relationship between variables

children.html: iii
i+1i+1i+1
xi+1=Aixi+bi\mathbf{x}_{i+1} = \mathbf{A}_{i} \mathbf{x}_i + \mathbf{b}_ixi+1​=Ai​xi​+bi​

children.value: However, we know that in reality things do not work that way, and we will usually have errors produced by noise in our sensors or actuators. The most common way to address this problem is adding some

children.html: ηi∼Gaussian(02×1,Σi)\eta_i\sim Gaussian(\mathbf{0}_{2\times1}, \Sigma_i)ηi​∼Gaussian(02×1​,Σi​)

children.value: to our model to represent this uncertainty:

children.html: xi+1=Aixi+bi+ηi\mathbf{x}_{i+1} = \mathbf{A}_{i}\mathbf{x}_i + \mathbf{b}_i + \eta_ixi+1​=Ai​xi​+bi​+ηi​

children.value: We can recognize here the typical
we use in Kalman filter for instance, that describes how our state evolves. We say that the noise we introduced on the right side states that our next state

children.html: xi+1\mathbf{x}_{i+1}xi+1​
Aixi+bi\mathbf{A}_{i}\mathbf{x}_i + \mathbf{b}_iAi​xi​+bi​
Σi\Sigma_iΣi​

children.value: describes the region where we expect

children.html: xi+1\mathbf{x}_{i+1}xi+1​

children.value: We can also notice that with a bit of manipulation, it is possible to establish the following relationship:

children.html: ηi=xi+1−Aixi−bi\eta_i = \mathbf{x}_{i+1} - \mathbf{A}_{i}\mathbf{x}_i - \mathbf{b}_iηi​=xi+1​−Ai​xi​−bi​

children.value: This is an important expression because we know that the left-hand expression follows a Gaussian distribution. But since we have an equivalence, the right-hand term must do as well. We must note here that what distributes as a Gaussian is neither

children.html: xi\mathbf{x}_{i}xi​
xi+1\mathbf{x}_{i+1}xi+1​
(xi+1−Aixi−bi)(\mathbf{x}_{i+1} - \mathbf{A}_{i}\mathbf{x}_i - \mathbf{b}_i)(xi+1​−Ai​xi​−bi​)

children.value: . This allows us to use the difference as an

children.html: xi\mathbf{x}_ixi​
xi+1\mathbf{x}_{i+1}xi+1​
(xi+1−Aixi−bi)∼Gaussian(02×1,Σi)(\mathbf{x}_{i+1} - \mathbf{A}_{i}\mathbf{x}_i - \mathbf{b}_i) \sim Gaussian(\mathbf{0}_{2\times1}, \Sigma_i)(xi+1​−Ai​xi​−bi​)∼Gaussian(02×1​,Σi​)

children.value: Solving the factor graph using the previous expression for the odometry factors is equivalent to solve the following least squares problem under the assumption that all our factors are Gaussian and we use
(MAP) estimation, which is fortunately our case:

children.html: X∗=arg min⁡∑i∣∣Aixi+bi−xi+1∣∣Σi2\mathcal{X}^{*} = \argmin\displaystyle\sum_{i} || \mathbf{A}_i \mathbf{x}_{i} + \mathbf{b}_{i} - {\mathbf{x}_{i+1}} ||^{2}_{\Sigma_i}X∗=argmini∑​∣∣Ai​xi​+bi​−xi+1​∣∣Σi​2​

children.value: Please note here that while we swapped the terms in the factor to be consistent with GTSAM’s documentation, it does not affect the formulation since the term is squared.

The previous optimization problem is linear with respect to the variables, hence solvable in closed form. By differentiating the squared cost, setting it to zero and doing some manipulation, we end up with the so-called
, which are particularly relevant for our posterior analysis:

children.html: =ATΣ−1A X∗=ATΣ−1b= \mathbf{A}^{T} \Sigma^{-1} \mathbf{A}\ \mathcal{X}^{*} = \mathbf{A}^{T} \Sigma^{-1} \mathbf{b}=ATΣ−1A X∗=ATΣ−1b
X∗\mathcal{X}^{*}X∗

children.value: stacks all the variables in the problem,

children.html: A\mathbf{A}A

children.value: is a matrix that stacks the linear terms in the factors, and

children.html: b\mathbf{b}b

children.value: does the same for the constant vector terms.
First point to note here is that finding the solution

children.html: X∗\mathcal{X}^{*}X∗
ATΣ−1A\mathbf{A}^{T} \Sigma^{-1} \mathbf{A}ATΣ−1A

children.value: , which in general is hard since it can be huge and dense in some parts. However we know that there are clever ways to solve it, such as iSAM and iSAM2 that GTSAM already implements, which are covered in
by Frank Dellaert and Michael Kaess.
When solving the normal equations, the left-hand side is known as the Fisher information matrix or Hessian. Its inverse approximates the covariance of the least squares solution.
Our interest in this matrix, though, known as
(since it approximates the Hessian of the original quadratic cost), is that its inverse

children.html: Σ∗=(ATΣ−1A)−1\Sigma^{*} = (\mathbf{A}^{T} \Sigma^{-1} \mathbf{A})^{-1}Σ∗=(ATΣ−1A)−1

children.value: also approximates the covariance of our solution - known as
). This is a quite important result because by solving the factor graph we are not only recovering an estimate of the mean of the solution but also a measure of its uncertainty. In GTSAM, the
class implements this procedure and a example can be further explored in the
As a result, we can say that after solving the factor graph the

children.html: Gaussian(X∗,Σ∗)Gaussian(\mathcal{X}^{*}, \Sigma^{*})Gaussian(X∗,Σ∗)

children.value: The previous pose graph was quite simple and probably not applicable for most of our problems. Having linear factors as the previous one is an
for most of the applications. It is more realistic to think that our state

children.html: i+1i+1i+1

children.value: will evolve as a nonlinear function of the state

children.html: iii

children.value: and the measurements, which is more general than the formerly assummed linear model

children.html: Aixi+bi\mathbf{A}_{i} \mathbf{x}_i + \mathbf{b}_iAi​xi​+bi​
xi+1=f(xi)\mathbf{x}_{i+1} = f(\mathbf{x}_i)xi+1​=f(xi​)

children.value: Despite nonlinear, we can still say that our mapping has some errors involved, which are embeded into a zero-mean Gaussian noise that we can simply add as before:

children.html: xi+1=f(xi)+ηi\mathbf{x}_{i+1} = f(\mathbf{x}_i) + \eta_ixi+1​=f(xi​)+ηi​

children.value: Following a similar procedure as before isolating the noise, we can reformulate the problem as the following

children.html: X=arg min⁡∑i∣∣f(xi)−xi+1∣∣Σi2\mathcal{X} = \argmin \displaystyle\sum_i || f(\mathbf{x}_i) - \mathbf{x}_{i+1} ||^2_{\Sigma_i}X=argmini∑​∣∣f(xi​)−xi+1​∣∣Σi​2​

children.value: Since the system is not linear with respect to the variables anymore we cannot solve it in close form. We need to use nonlinear optimization algorithms such as
. They will try to approximate our
by linearizing the residual with respect to some

kkk
f(xi)≈f(xˉk)+H(xˉk)xi=bk+Hkxif(\mathbf{x}_i) \approx f(\mathbf{\bar{x}}^{k}) + \mathbf{H}(\mathbf{\bar{x}}^{k})\mathbf{x}_i = \mathbf{b}_k + \mathbf{H}^k \mathbf{x}_if(xi​)≈f(xˉk)+H(xˉk)xi​=bk​+Hkxi​
H(xˉk)\mathbf{H}(\mathbf{\bar{x}}^{k})H(xˉk)
f(⋅)f(\cdot)f(⋅)
xˉk\mathbf{\bar{x}}^{k}xˉk

δXk=arg min⁡∑i∣∣Hkxi+bi−xi+1∣∣Σik2\delta\mathcal{X}^{k}= \argmin \displaystyle\sum_i || \mathbf{H}^k\mathbf{x}_i + \mathbf{b}_i - \mathbf{x}_{i+1} ||^2_{\Sigma_i^k}δXk=argmini∑​∣∣Hkxi​+bi​−xi+1​∣∣Σik​2​

children.value: It is important to observe here that we are not obtaining the global solution

δXk\delta\mathcal{X}^{k}δXk

children.value: that will allow us to move closer to some minima that depends on the initial values. This linear problem
be solved in closed form as we did before. In fact, the normal equations now become something similar to the linear case:

children.label: nonlinear-normal-equations
children.html: (Hk)T(Σk)−1 Hk δX=(Hk)T(Σk)−1b(\mathbf{H}^k)^{T} (\Sigma^{k})^{-1}\ \mathbf{H}^k\ \delta\mathcal{X} = (\mathbf{H}^k)^{T} (\Sigma^{k})^{-1} \mathbf{b}(Hk)T(Σk)−1 Hk δX=(Hk)T(Σk)−1b
Hk\mathbf{H}^kHk

children.value: is built by stacking the Jacobians at iteration

children.html: kkk
δXk\delta\mathcal{X}^{k}δXk

children.value: will be used to update our current solution at iteration

children.html: kkk
Xk+1=Xk+δXk\mathcal{X}^{k+1} = \mathcal{X}^k + \delta\mathcal{X}^{k}Xk+1=Xk+δXk
Xk+1\mathcal{X}^{k+1}Xk+1

children.value: corresponds to the best estimate so far, and can be used as a new linearization point for a next iteration.
Similarly, the expression on the left-hand side

children.html: Σk+1=((Hk)T(Σk)−1Hk)−1\Sigma^{k+1} = ((\mathbf{H}^k)^{T} (\Sigma^{k})^{-1} \mathbf{H}^k)^{-1}Σk+1=((Hk)T(Σk)−1Hk)−1

children.value: also corresponds to the Fisher information or Hessian as before,
but with respect to the linearization point
. This is quite important because both the best solution so far

children.html: Xk+1\mathcal{X}^{k+1}Xk+1
Σk+1\Sigma^{k+1}Σk+1

children.value: will be valid only at this linearization point and will change with every iteration of the nonlinear optimization. But understanding this, we still can say that

children.html: k+1k+1k+1

children.value: our best solution will follow a distribution

children.html: Gaussian(Xk+1,Σk+1)Gaussian(\mathcal{X}^{k+1}, \Sigma^{k+1})Gaussian(Xk+1,Σk+1)

children.value: In this first post we reviewed the basics ideas to solve factor graphs and extract estimates from them. We showed how the linear problem described by the

not only allows us to find the solution, but also encodes information about its covariance—given by the inverse of the Fisher information matrix. Additionally, in the context of nonlinear problems, we showed how
such covariance is only valid around the linearization point
we will review how these ideas generalize when we are not estimating
variables anymore but other objects such as rotation matrices and rigid-body transformations—generally known as

. While this will introduce a bit of complexity not only in the maths but also the notation, by being explicit about our conventions we will be able to consistently solve a wider set of problems usually found in robotics and computer vision.
